children.title: What equipment is part of Dry System?
Sprinkler heads free of corrosion, foreign material, paint or damage, no signs of leakage and heads installed in proper orientation (5.2.1.1.1)
children.hint: 5.2.1.1.1 Sprinklers shall not show signs of leakage; shall be free of corrosion, foreign materials, paint, and physical damage; and shall be installed in the correct orientation (e.g., upright, pendent, or sidewall).

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Minimum clearance to storage maintained below sprinkler deflectors. (5.2.1.2)
children.hint: 5.2.1.2 The minimum clearance to storage as described in 5.2.1.2.1 through 5.2.1.2.6 shall be maintained below all sprinkler deflectors. 5.2.1.2.2 Where standards other than NFPA 13..., specify greater clearance to storage minimums, they shall be followed. 5.2.1.2.3 Clearance between the deflector and the top of storage shall be 36 in. (914 mm) or greater for special sprinklers. 5.2.1.2.4 Clearance from the top of storage to sprinkler deflectors shall be 36 in. (914 mm) or greater where rubber tires are stored. 5.2.1.2.5 In-rack sprinklers shall not be required to meet the obstruction criteria and clearance from storage requirements. 5.2.1.2.6 Clearance between the deflector and the top of storage shall be permitted to be less than 18 in. (457 mm) where shown to be permitted by the installation standard.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Escutcheons and coverplates in place, if applicable. (5.2.1.1.5)
children.hint: 5.2.1.1.5  Escutcheons and coverplates for recessed, flush, and concealed sprinklers shall be replaced with their listed escutcheon or coverplate if found missing during the inspection.  5.2.1.1.5.1 Where the listed escutcheon or coverplate from a listed assembly is missing and is no longer commercially available, the sprinkler shall be replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Number of replacement sprinkler heads per number installed in the head box comply: 6 per 1-300: 12 per 301 to 1,000: 24 per 1,000 (5.4.1.5)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.4 The stock of spare sprinklers shall include all types and ratings installed and shall be as follows: (1) For protected facilities having under 300 sprinklers—no fewer than 6 sprinklers (2) For protected facilities having 300 to 1000 sprinklers — no fewer than 12 sprinklers (3) For protected facilities having over 1000 sprinklers — no fewer than 24 sprinklers

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sprinkler head wrench for each type head provided in head box (5.4.1.5.5)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.5 One sprinkler wrench as specified by the sprinkler manufacturer shall be provided in the cabinet for each type of sprinkler installed to be used for the removal and installation of sprinklers in the system.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
List of sprinklers installed on the property posted on sprinkler cabinet. (5.4.1.5.6)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.6 A list of the sprinklers installed in the property shall be posted in the sprinkler cabinet.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, leaks, corrosion, misalignment, or other loads or pipe hung from system (5.2.2)
children.hint: 5.2.2.1 Pipe and fittings shall be in good condition and free of mechanical damage, leakage, and corrosion. 5.2.2.2 Sprinkler piping shall not be subjected to external loads by materials either resting on the pipe or hung from the pipe.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pipe hangers and seismic braces secure and undamaged (5.2.3)
children.hint: 5.2.3 Sprinkler pipe hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected annually from the floor level. 5.2.3.1 Hangers, braces, and supports shall not be damaged, loose, or unattached. 5.2.3.2 Hangers, braces, and supports that are damaged, loose, or unattached shall be replaced or refastened.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sprinklers  in service 50 years has been replaced or sample tested?  (5.3.1.1.1)
children.hint: 5.3.1.1.1 Where sprinklers have been in service for 50 years, they shall be replaced or representative samples from one or more sample areas shall be tested. 5.3.1.1.1.1 Test procedures shall be repeated at 10-year intervals.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Date replaced or last sample taken.
Sprinklers with fast response elements older than 20 years, have been replaced or sample tested? (5.3.1.1.1.3)
children.hint: 5.3.1.1.1.3 Sprinklers manufactured using fast-response elements that have been in service for 20 years shall be replaced or representative samples shall be tested and then retested at 10-year intervals.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Date replaced or last sample taken
Dry sprinklers in service for 10 years have been replaced or sample tested? (5.3.1.1.1.6)
children.hint: 5.3.1.1.1.6 Dry sprinklers that have been in service for 10 years shall be replaced or representative samples shall be tested and then retested at 10-year intervals.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Date replaced or last sample taken
children.hint: Enter date mm/yy

children.title: Air and water pressure gauges operating properly (13.2.7.1)
children.hint: 13.2.7.1.1 Gauges shall be inspected monthly to verify that the gauge is operable and not physically damaged.  13.2.7.1.2 Gauges monitoring water pressure shall be inspected quarterly to verify that normal water supply pressure is being maintained.  13.2.7.1.3 Gauges monitoring air or nitrogen pressure shall be inspected monthly to verify that normal air or nitrogen pressure are being maintained.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve free of physical damage, trim valves in normal position and intermediate chamber not leaking. (13.4.4.1.4)
children.hint: 13.3.2.2 The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (1) In the normal open or closed position (2)*Sealed, locked, or supervised (3) Accessible (4) Post indicator valves (PIVs) are provided with correct wrenches (5) Free from external leaks (6) Provided with applicable identification

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve free of leaks, properly secured, appropriate wrench available, if applicable and identification signs in place. (13.3.2.2)
children.hint: 13.3.2.2 The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (1) In the normal open or closed position (2)*Sealed, locked, or supervised (3) Accessible (4) Post indicator valves (PIVs) are provided with correct wrenches (5) Free from external leaks (6) Provided with applicable identification

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydraulic nameplate securely attached and legible (5.2.5)
children.hint: 5.2.5  The hydraulic design information sign shall be inspected annually to verify that it is provided, attached securely to the sprinkler riser, and is legible.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Information sign securely attached and legible. (5.2.7)
children.hint: 5.2.7 Information Sign. The information sign required by 4.1.9 shall be inspected annually to verify that it is provided, securely attached, and legible. 4.1.9.1 A permanently marked metal or rigid plastic information sign shall be placed at the system control riser supplying an antifreeze loop, dry system, preaction system, or auxiliary system control valve. 4.1.9.2 Each sign shall be secured with a corrosion-resistant wire, chain, or other approved means and shall indicate at least the following information: (1) Location of the area served by the system (2) Location of auxiliary drains and low-point drains for dry pipe and preaction systems (3) The presence and location of antifreeze or other auxiliary systems (4) The presence and location(s) of heat tape

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
If system has auxiliary drains, is sign in place indicating number and location of each drain (13.4.5.1.2)
children.hint: 13.4.5.1.2 Systems with auxiliary drains shall require a sign at the dry valve indicating the number of auxiliary drains and the location of each individual drain.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Priming water level correct (13.4.5.2.1)
children.hint: 13.4.5.2.1 The priming water level shall be tested quarterly.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Partial trip test of the dry pipe valve conducted with control valve partially opened (13.4.5.2.2.3)
children.hint: 13.4.5.2.2.3 During those years when full flow testing in accordance with 13.4.5.2.2.2 is not required, each dry pipe valve shall be trip tested with the control valve partially open.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Air pressure (psi) at trip of dry valve. (A.13.4.5.2.2.3)
children.hint: A.13.4.5.2.2.3 A partial flow trip test is conducted in the following manner: (4) Record the system air or nitrogen pressure and the supply water pressure (6) Note and record the air or nitrogen pressure and supply water pressure when the dry pipe valve trips

children.title: Time (sec) between start of test and trip of valve. (A.13.4.5.2.2.3)
children.hint: A.13.4.5.2.2.3 A partial flow trip test is conducted in the following manner: (4) Record the system air or nitrogen pressure and the supply water pressure (6) Note and record the air or nitrogen pressure and supply water pressure when the dry pipe valve trips

children.title: Internal inspection - components operate properly and move freely, valve cleaned and in good condition (13.4.4.3.1)
children.hint: 13.4.4.3.1 During the annual trip test, the interior of the dry pipe valve shall be cleaned thoroughly, and parts replaced or repaired as necessary.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Auxiliary drains and low-point drains opened, pipe drained or where weep holes provided, inspected to ensure they are clear and unobstructed (13.4.5.3.2)
children.hint: 13.4.5.3.2 Auxiliary drains in dry pipe sprinkler systems shall be drained after each operation of the system, before the onset of freezing weather conditions, and thereafter as needed.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Full flow trip test of dry valve conducted with control valve opened fully (13.4.5.2.2.2)
children.hint: 13.4.3.2.2 Except for preaction systems covered by 13.4.3.2.4, every 3 years the preaction valve shall be trip tested with the control valve fully open.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System testing for air leakage (13.4.5.2.9)
children.hint: 13.4.5.2.9 Dry pipe systems shall be tested once every 3 years for gas leakage

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Time (sec) between start of test and water flow from inspectors test connection. (A.13.4.5.2.2.2(5))
children.hint: A.13.4.5.2.2.2 A full flow trip test generally requires at least two individuals, one of whom is situated at the dry pipe valve while the other is at the inspector’s test. If possible, they should be in communication with each other. A full flow trip test is conducted as follows: (5) Testers at the inspector’s test note the time at which water flows steadily from the test connection. This time is noted for comparison purposes to previous tests and is not meant to be a specific pass/fail criterion.

children.title: Valve Status Test - Valves open when returned to service. (13.3.3.4)
children.hint: 13.3.3.4  A valve status test shall be conducted any time the control valve is closed and reopened at system riser.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve strainers, filters, and restriction orifices; free from obstructions, operating properly, and in good condition (13.4.5.1.5)
children.hint: 13.4.5.1.5 Strainers, filters, and restricted orifices shall be inspected internally every 5 years unless tests indicate a greater frequency is necessary.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge error less than 3% full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.7.2)
children.hint: 13.2.7.2 Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge.  13.2.7.3 Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Dry sprinkler system auxiliary drain(s) drained as needed during this inspection (13.4.5.3.2)
children.hint: 13.4.5.3.2 Auxiliary drains in dry pipe sprinkler systems shall be drained after each operation of the system, before the onset of freezing weather conditions, and thereafter as needed.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Compressor free of physical damage and operating properly.  (13.10.2.1)
children.hint: 13.10.2.1  Air compressors dedicated to water-based fire protection systems shall be inspected monthly to verify the following:  (1) Air compressor is free of physical damage.   (2) Power wiring to the air compressor is intact and free of physical damage.  (3) Piping from the air compressor to the fire protection system is intact and free of physical damage.  (4) The means of anchoring the air compressor to the structure or to the system piping is secure, tight, and free of physical damage.  (5) Air compressors requiring oil have the required amount of oil in the oil reservoir

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Compressor operates on drop of air pressure, normal pressure restored, without over heating. (13.10.3.1)
children.hint: 13.10.3.1 Air compressors dedicated to water-based fire protection systems shall be tested annually to verify the following:  (1) Air compressor operates as intended on the proper drop of air pressure in the fire protection system.  (2) Air compressor restores normal air pressure in the fire protection system in the required time frame.  (3) Air compressor does not overheat while running.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Compressor been maintained (13.10.4.1)
children.hint: 13.10.4.1 Air compressors dedicated to water-based fire protection systems shall be maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.  13.10.4.2 Compressors requiring oil shall have the oil replaced on an annual basis unless the manufacturer's instructions require more frequent replacement.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Automatic air maintenance device pressure maintained at proper setting for system (13.4.5.2.8)
children.hint: 13.4.5.2.8 Automatic air pressure maintenance devices, if provided, shall be tested annually during the dry pipe valve trip test in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Exterior in good condition, free from leakage and gauge operable (13.4.5.1.3)
children.hint: 13.4.5.1.3 The dry pipe valve shall be externally inspected monthly to verify the following:  (1) The valve is free of physical damage.  (2) All trim valves are in the appropriate open or closed position.  (3) The intermediate chamber is not leaking.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pressure (psi) shown on gauge.
children.hint: Record the pressure (psi) shown on the pressure gauge.

children.title: Gauge indicating same pressure as air gauge on valve (13.2.7.1.3.1)
children.hint: 13.2.7.1.3.1 The gauge on the quick-opening device, if provided, shall indicate the same pressure as the gauge on the system side of the dry pipe valve.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
QOD tested and working properly (13.4.5.2.4)
children.hint: 13.4.5.2.4* Quick-opening devices, if provided, shall be tested quarterly.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Internal inspection - all components operate properly, move freely and in good condition (13.4.5.1.4)
children.hint: 13.4.5.1.4 The interior of the dry pipe valve shall be inspected annually when the trip test is conducted.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
What equipment is part of Wet System?
Sprinkler heads appear free of corrosion, foreign material, paint or damage, no signs of leakage and heads/deflectors installed in proper orientation.   (5.2.1.1.1)
children.hint: 5.2.1.1.1 Any sprinkler that shows signs of any of the following shall be replaced:  (1) Leakage  (2) Corrosion detrimental to sprinkler performance  (3) Physical damage  (4) Loss of fluid in the glass bulb heat-responsive element  (5) Loading detrimental to sprinkler performance  (6) Paint other than that applied by the sprinkler manufacturer

Escutcheons and coverplates in place, if applicable. (5.2.1.1.5)
children.hint: 5.2.1.1.5 Escutcheons and coverplates for recessed, flush, and concealed sprinklers shall be replaced with their listed escutcheon or coverplate if found missing during the inspection.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Minimum clearance to storage maintained below sprinkler deflectors. (5.2.1.2)
children.hint: 5.2.1.2 The minimum clearance to storage as described in 5.2.1.2.1 through 5.2.1.2.6 shall be maintained below all sprinkler deflectors.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
# of replacement sprinkler heads per # installed in head box comply: 6 per 1-300: 12 per 301 to 1,000: 24 per 1,000 (5.4.1.5)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.4 The stock of spare sprinklers shall include all types and ratings installed and shall be as follows: (1) For protected facilities having under 300 sprinklers—no fewer than 6 sprinklers (2) For protected facilities having 300 to 1000 sprinklers — no fewer than 12 sprinklers (3) For protected facilities having over 1000 sprinklers — no fewer than 24 sprinklers

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sprinkler head wrench for each type head provided in head box (5.4.1.5.5)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.5 One sprinkler wrench as specified by the sprinkler manufacturer shall be provided in the cabinet for each type of sprinkler installed to be used for the removal and installation of sprinklers in the system.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
List of sprinklers installed on the property posted on head box. (5.4.1.5.6)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.6 A list of the sprinklers installed in the property shall be posted in the sprinkler cabinet.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping and fittings free of mechanical damage, leaks, corrosion, misalignment, or other loads or pipe hung from system (5.2.2)
children.hint: 5.2.2.1 Pipe and fittings shall be in good condition and free of mechanical damage, leakage, and corrosion. 5.2.2.2 Sprinkler piping shall not be subjected to external loads by materials either resting on the pipe or hung from the pipe.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pipe hangers and seismic braces secure and undamaged (5.2.3)
children.hint: 5.2.3.1 Hangers and seismic braces shall not be damaged, loose, or unattached. 5.2.3.2 Hangers and seismic braces that are damaged, loose, or unattached shall be replaced or refastened.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sprinklers in service 50 years has been replaced or sample tested? (5.3.1.1.1)
children.hint: 5.3.1.1.1 Where sprinklers have been in service for 50 years, they shall be replaced or representative samples from one or more sample areas shall be tested. 5.3.1.1.1.1 Test procedures shall be repeated at 10-year intervals.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Date replaced or last sample taken.
Sprinklers with fast response elements in service 20 years, have been replaced or sample tested?  (5.3.1.1.1.3)
children.hint: 5.3.1.1.1.3 Sprinklers manufactured using fast-response elements that have been in service for 20 years shall be replaced or representative samples shall be tested and then retested at 10-year intervals.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Date replaced or las sample taken.
Water pressure gauges operating properly (13.4.1.1)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1 Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected monthly and shall verify the following: (1) The gauges indicate normal supply water pressure is being maintained.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pressure (psi) shown on System side pressure gauge.
children.hint: Record the pressure (psi) shown on the System side pressure gauge.

children.title: Exterior of valve free of physical damage, valves in normal position (13.4.1.1)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1 Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected monthly and shall verify the following: (2) The valve is free of physical damage. (3) All valves are in the appropriate open or closed position.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve free of leaks, properly secured, appropriate wrench available, if applicable and identification signs in place. (13.3.2.2)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1 Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected monthly and shall verify the following: (2) The valve is free of physical damage. (3) All valves are in the appropriate open or closed position.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Retard chamber and alarm drains free from leakage (13.4.1.1)
children.hint: 13.4.1.1 Alarm valves and system riser check valves shall be externally inspected monthly and shall verify the following: (4) The retarding chamber or alarm drains are not leaking.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydraulic nameplate securely attached and is legible (5.2.5)
children.hint: 5.2.5 Hydraulic Design Information Sign. The hydraulic design information sign shall be inspected annually to verify that it is provided, attached securely to the sprinkler riser, and is legible.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Information sign securely attached and legible. (5.2.8)
children.hint: 5.2.8 Information Sign. The information sign required by 4.1.9 shall be inspected annually to verify that it is provided, securely attached, and legible.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve Status Test - Valves open when returned to service. (13.3.3.4)
children.hint: 13.3.3.4 A valve status test shall be conducted any time the control valve is closed and reopened at system riser.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Internal inspection - all components operate properly and move freely, valve cleaned and in good condition (13.4.2.1)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Internally inspect valve strainers, filters, and restriction orifices; free from obstructions, operating properly, and in good condition (13.4.1.2)
children.hint: 13.4.1.2 Alarm valves and their associated strainers, filters, and restriction orifices shall be inspected internally every 5 years unless tests indicate a greater frequency is necessary.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge, error is less than 3% full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.7.2)
children.hint: 13.2.7.2 Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge. 13.2.7.3 Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Exterior of valve in good condition and both gauges operable (13.2.7.1.1)
children.hint: 13.2.7.1.1 Gauges shall be inspected monthly to verify that the gauge is operable and not physically damaged. 13.2.7.1.3.2 Where air pressure supervision is connected to a constantly attended location, gauges shall be inspected quarterly.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pressure (psi) shown on System side pressure gauge.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve Status Test - Valves open when returned to service. (13.3.3.4)
children.hint: 13.3.3.4  A valve status test shall be conducted any time the control valve is closed and reopened at system riser.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Internal inspection - all components operate properly, move freely and in good condition (13.4.2.1)
children.hint: 13.4.2.1 Inspection. Valves shall be inspected internally every 5 years to verify that all components operate correctly, move freely, and are in good condition.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge is error less than 3% full or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced.  (13.2.7.2)
children.hint: 13.2.7.2 Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge. 13.2.7.3 Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced.

Sprinkler heads free of corrosion, foreign material, paint or damage, no signs of leakage and heads installed in proper orientation (5.2.1.1)
children.hint: 5.2.1.1.1 Sprinklers shall not show signs of leakage; shall be free of corrosion, foreign materials, paint, and physical damage; and shall be installed in the correct orientation (e.g., upright, pendent, or sidewall).

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Escutcheons and coverplates in place, if applicable. (5.2.1.1.5)
children.hint: 5.2.1.1.5 Escutcheons and coverplates for recessed, flush, and concealed sprinklers shall be replaced with their listed escutcheon or coverplate if found missing during the inspection. 5.2.1.1.5.1 Where the listed escutcheon or coverplate from a listed assembly is missing and is no longer commercially available, the sprinkler shall be replaced.

Minimum clearance to storage maintained below sprinkler deflectors. (5.2.1.2)
children.hint: 5.2.1.2 The minimum clearance to storage as described in 5.2.1.2.1 through 5.2.1.2.6 shall be maintained below all sprinkler deflectors.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Number of replacement sprinkler heads per number installed in the head box comply: 6 per 1-300: 12 per 301 to 1,000: 24 per 1,000 (5.4.1.5)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5 A supply of at least six spare sprinklers shall be maintained on the premises so that any sprinklers that have operated or been damaged in any way can be promptly replaced. 5.4.1.5.4 The stock of spare sprinklers shall include all types and ratings installed and shall be as follows: (1) For protected facilities having under 300 sprinklers—no fewer than 6 sprinklers (2) For protected facilities having 300 to 1000 sprinklers — no fewer than 12 sprinklers (3) For protected facilities having over 1000 sprinklers — no fewer than 24 sprinklers

Sprinkler head wrench for each type head provided in head box (5.4.1.5.5)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.5 One sprinkler wrench as specified by the sprinkler manufacturer shall be provided in the cabinet for each type of sprinkler installed to be used for the removal and installation of sprinklers in the system.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
List of sprinklers installed on the property posted on head box. (5.4.1.5.6)
children.hint: 5.4.1.5.6 A list of the sprinklers installed in the property shall be posted in the sprinkler cabinet.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, leaks, corrosion, misalignment, or other loads or pipe hung from system (5.2.2)
children.hint: 5.2.2.1 Pipe and fittings shall be in good condition and free of mechanical damage, leakage, and corrosion. 5.2.2.2 Sprinkler piping shall not be subjected to external loads by materials either resting on the pipe or hung from the pipe.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pipe hangers and seismic braces secure and undamaged (5.2.3)
children.hint: 5.2.3 Sprinkler pipe hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected annually from the floor level. 5.2.3.1 Hangers, braces, and supports shall not be damaged, loose, or unattached. 5.2.3.2 Hangers, braces, and supports that are damaged, loose, or unattached shall be replaced or refastened.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sprinklers in service 50 years has been replaced or sample tested? (5.3.1.1.1)
children.hint: 5.3.1.1.1 Where sprinklers have been in service for 50 years, they shall be replaced or representative samples from one or more sample areas shall be tested. 5.3.1.1.1.1 Test procedures shall be repeated at 10-year intervals.

children.hint: 5.2.5 Hydraulic Design Information Sign. The hydraulic design information sign shall be inspected quarterly to verify that it is provided, attached securely to the sprinkler riser, and is legible.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Information sign securely attached and legible. (5.2.7)
children.hint: 5.2.7 Information Sign. The information sign required by 4.1.9 shall be inspected annually to verify that it is provided, securely attached, and legible. 4.1.9.1 A permanently marked metal or rigid plastic information sign shall be placed at the system control riser supplying an antifreeze loop, dry system, preaction system, or auxiliary system control valve. 4.1.9.2 Each sign shall be secured with a corrosion-resistant wire, chain, or other approved means and shall indicate at least the following information: (1) Location of the area served by the system (2) Location of auxiliary drains and low-point drains for dry pipe and preaction systems (3) The presence and location of antifreeze or other auxiliary systems (4) The presence and location(s) of heat tape

children.hint: 13.3.3.4 A valve status test shall be conducted any time the control valve is closed and reopened at system riser.

Interior of valve cleaned thoroughly, components move freely. (13.4.3.1.4)

children.hint: 13.4.3.2.6 Manual Operation. Manual actuation devices shall be operated annually.

Full flow trip test conducted with control valve open (13.4.3.2.2)

children.hint: 13.4.3.2.9 Records indicating the date the preaction valve was last tripped and the tripping time, as well as the individual and organization conducting the test, shall be maintained at a location or in a manner readily available for review by the authority having jurisdiction.

children.title: Time (sec) between start of test and water flow from inspectors test connection. (13.4.3.2.9)
children.hint: 13.4.3.2.9 Records indicating the date the preaction valve was last tripped and the tripping time, as well as the individual and organization conducting the test, shall be maintained at a location or in a manner readily available for review by the authority having jurisdiction.

children.title: System testing for air leakage (13.4.3.2.5)
children.hint: 13.4.3.2.5 Preaction systems shall be tested once every 3 years for air leakage, using one of the following test methods: (1) A pressure test at 40 psi (3.2 bar) for 2 hours. The system shall be permitted to lose up to 3 psi (0.2 bar) during the duration of the test. Air leaks shall be addressed if the system loses more than 3 psi (0.2 bar) during this test. (2) With the system at normal system pressure, shut off the air source (compressor or shop air) for 4 hours. If the low air pressure alarm goes off within this period, the air leaks shall be addressed.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue

children.hint: 13.4.3.1.5 Strainers, filters, restricted orifices, and diaphragm chambers shall be inspected internally every 5 years unless tests indicate a greater frequency is necessary.

(2) Air compressor restores normal air pressure in the fire protection system in the required time frame. (3) Air compressor does not overheat while running.

children.hint: 5.3.3 (1) Using the antifreeze information sign required by 4.1.10, installation records, maintenance records, information from the owner, chemical tests, or other reliable sources of information, the type of antifreeze in the system shall be determined

children.title: Record percentage of Solution mix. (5.3.3.4.1)
children.hint: 5.3.3.4.1 For systems installed prior to September 30, 2012, listed antifreeze solutions shall not be required until September 30, 2022, where one of the following conditions is met: (1) The concentration of the antifreeze solution shall be limited to 30% propylene glycol by volume or 38% glycerine by volume. (2) Antifreeze systems with concentrations in excess of 30 % but not more than 40% propylene glycol by volume and 38% but not more than 50% glycerine by volume shall be permitted based upon an approved deterministic risk assessment prepared by a qualified person approved by the authority having jurisdiction.

children.title: Information sign securely attached and legible. (4.1.10)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, leaks, undamaged control valves, support device in place and without damage, supervisory signal undamaged. (6.2.4.1)
children.hint: 6.2.4.1 Piping shall be inspected annually for the following conditions:  (1) Damaged piping   (2) Damaged control valves   (3) Missing or damaged pipe support device (i.e., missing or damaged hanger or seismic brace)   (4) Damaged supervisory signal initiating device

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydraulic design sign, if provided, legible and secure. (6.2.2.1)
children.hint: 6.2.2.1 A hydraulic design information sign that is missing or illegible shall be replaced. 6.2.2.2 A standpipe system that was not sized by hydraulic design shall have a hydraulic design information sign that reads “Pipe Schedule System.”

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Automatic standpipe systems had successful flow test at hydraulically most remote hose valve connection. (6.3.1)
children.hint: 6.3.1.1 A flow test shall be conducted every 5 years on all automatic standpipe systems to verify that the required flow and pressure are available at the hydraulically most remote hose valve outlet(s) while flowing the standpipe system demand.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pitot Pressure - Flow Test
children.hint: 6.3.1.1 A flow test shall be conducted every 5 years on all automatic standpipe systems to verify that the required flow and pressure are available at the hydraulically most remote hose valve outlet(s) while flowing the standpipe system demand.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on gauge at top of riser with designed flow flowing.
children.hint: Record pressure (psi) shown on gauge at top of riser with designed flow flowing.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge under no flow conditions.
children.hint: Record pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge under no flow conditions.

children.title: Pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge with designed flow flowing.
children.hint: Record pressure (psi) shown on supply gauge with designed flow flowing.

children.title: Flow (gpm) at most remote outlet  (6.3.1.1)
children.hint: 6.3.1.1 A flow test shall be conducted every 5 years on all automatic standpipe systems to verify that the required flow and pressure are available at the hydraulically most remote hose valve outlet(s) while flowing the standpipe system demand.  6.3.1.3 Class II standpipe system demand shall include 100 gpm (379 L/min) for the most remote standpipe connection.

children.title: Hydrostatic Test results (6.3.2.1)
children.hint: 6.3.2.1 Hydrostatic tests of not less than 200 psi (13.8 bar) pressure for 2 hours, or at 50 psi (3.4 bar) in excess of the maximum pressure, where maximum pressure is in excess of 150 psi (10.3 bar), shall be conducted every 5 years on manual standpipe systems and semiautomatic dry standpipe systems, including piping in the fire department connection. 6.3.2.2 The hydrostatic test pressure shall be measured at the low elevation point of the individual system or zone being tested.  6.3.2.2.1 The inside standpipe piping shall show no leakage.

children.title: Hydrostatic Test pressure (psi) (6.3.2.2)
children.hint: 6.3.2.1 Hydrostatic tests of not less than 200 psi (13.8 bar) pressure for 2 hours, or at 50 psi (3.4 bar) in excess of the maximum pressure, where maximum pressure is in excess of 150 psi (10.3 bar), shall be conducted every 5 years on manual standpipe systems and semiautomatic dry standpipe systems, including piping in the fire department connection. 6.3.2.2 The hydrostatic test pressure shall be measured at the low elevation point of the individual system or zone being tested.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge error less than 3% full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced (13.2.7.2)
children.hint: 13.2.7.2 Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge. 13.2.7.3 Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sprinkler system auxiliary drain(s) drained as needed during this inspection. (Table 6.5.1)
children.hint: Table 6.5.1 Inspect for leaks at system working pressure.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cabinet and parts free from damage, corrosion, and visible or physical obstructions. (6.2.8.1)
children.hint: 6.2.8.1 Cabinets shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (1) Overall for corroded or damaged parts (8) Visible or physical obstructions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cabinet-break glass type, lock functioning properly, and break glass device attached. (6.2.8.1)
children.hint: 6.2.8.1 Cabinets shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (5) Lock on break glass–type cabinet not functioning properly (6) Glass break device missing or not attached.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cabinet identified as containing fire equipment. (6.2.8.1)
children.hint: 6.2.8.1 Cabinets shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (7) Not properly identified as containing fire equipment.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cabinet valves, hose, nozzle, fire extinguishers, etc. easily accessible. (6.2.8.1)
children.hint: 6.2.8.1 Cabinets shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (9) All valves, hose, nozzles, fire extinguishers, and so forth, easily accessible.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cap, valve handle, gaskets, and restricting device present and free from damage and deterioration. (6.2.3.1)
children.hint: 6.2.3.1 Hose connections shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (1) Valve cap(s) missing or damaged ( (3) Valve handles missing or damaged (4) Cap gaskets missing or deteriorated (7) Pressure restricting device missing

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hose connection without damage, valve free from leakage and no visible or physical obstruction. (6.2.3.1)
children.hint: 6.2.3.1 Hose connections shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: 2) Fire hose connection damaged (5) Valve leaking (6) Visible and physical obstructions to hose connections (9) Valve threads damaged.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve operates smoothly. (6.2.3.1)
children.hint: 6.2.3.1 Hose connections shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (8) Manual, semiautomatic, or dry standpipe valve does not operate smoothly

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Nozzle present, free of obstructions and operates smoothly. (6.2.6.1)
children.hint: 6.2.6.1 Hose nozzles shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (1) Hose nozzle missing (3) Obstructions (4) Does not operate smoothly.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Nozzle gaskets present and free of deterioration. (6.2.6.1)
children.hint: 6.2.6.1 Hose nozzles shall be inspected annually for the following conditions: (2) Gasket missing or deteriorated

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Standpipe System
children.hint: 13.2.7.1.2 Gauges monitoring water pressure shall be inspected quarterly to verify that normal water supply pressure is being maintained. 13.2.7.1.3 Gauges monitoring air or nitrogen pressure shall be inspected monthly to verify that normal air or nitrogen pressure are being maintained.

children.title: Water mist nozzles free of corrosion, leakage, external loading, or damage. (12.1.2.1.1)
children.hint: 12.1.2.1.1 Any water mist nozzle that shows signs of any of the following shall be replaced: (1) Leakage (2) Corrosion (3) Physical damage (4) Loss of fluid in the glass bulb heat responsive element (5)Loading (6) Painting, unless painted by the water mist nozzle manufacturer.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Nozzles in correct orientation. (12.1.2.1.2)
children.hint: 12.1.2.1.2 Any water mist nozzle that has been installed in the incorrect orientation shall be corrected by repositioning the branch line, drop, or sprig, or shall be replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Spare thermally activated nozzles for all types and ratings in place; 3 per 1-50: 6 per 50-300: 12 per 301-1000: 24 per +1000 (12.2.2.3.3)
children.hint: 12.2.2.3.3 The stock of spare thermally activated nozzles shall include all types and ratings installed and shall be as follows: (1) For systems having fewer than 50 nozzles, not fewer than 3 nozzles (2) For systems having 50 to 300 nozzles, not fewer than 6 nozzles (3) For systems having 301 to 1000 nozzles, not fewer than 12 nozzles (4) For systems having over 1000 nozzles, not fewer than 24 nozzles

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Water mist nozzle wrench for each type nozzle provided in cabinet. (12.2.2.4)
children.hint: 12.2.2.4 Where required by the manufacturer, a special water mist nozzle wrench shall be provided and kept in the cabinet to be used for the removal and installation of nozzles. 12.2.2.4.1 One water mist nozzle wrench shall be provided for each type of nozzle installed.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, leaks, corrosion, misalignment, or other loads or pipe hung from system (5.2.2)
children.hint: 5.2.2.1 Pipe and fittings shall be in good condition and free of mechanical damage, leakage, and corrosion. 5.2.2.2 Sprinkler piping shall not be subjected to external loads by materials either resting on the pipe or hung from the pipe.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Nozzles in service for 20 years replaced or samples tested (12.1.2.3.1)
children.hint: 12.1.2.3.1 Automatic water mist nozzles that have been in service for 20 years shall be replaced, or representative samples shall be tested and then retested at 10-year intervals.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Nozzles in harsh environments replaced or samples tested. (12.1.2.3.2)
children.hint: 12.1.2.3.2 Where water mist nozzles are subjected to harsh environments, including corrosive atmospheres and corrosive water supplies, they shall be either replaced or representative samples tested on a 5-year basis.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cylinders in good condition
children.hint: Inspection general condition, corrosion (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Quantity of additive agent adequate. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Quantity of additive agent adequate (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Additive tested for good quality. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Quality of additive tested (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Water level at appropriate position (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Water level at appropriate level. (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pressure during discharge at outlet as expected. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Test pressure at outlet during discharge. (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Test float-operated valve for operation. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Test operation of float-operated valve. (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Inspect and clean filters, strainers and cyclone separator. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Inspect and clean filters, strainers, cyclone separator. (Table 12.1.2)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cylinder control valve in open position, and cylinder pressure within specified limit. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Table 12.1.2 Confirm cylinder control valve is open. Inspect cylinder pressure.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Compressed gas cylinder pressure (psi) (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Indicate cylinder pressure

children.title: Support frame and restraints in place and secure. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Table 12.1.2 Inspect support frame and cylinder restraints.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cylinder capacity and pressure rating at required levels. Compressed gas meets required specifications. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Table 12.1.2 Inspect cylinder capacity and pressure rating. Confirm compressed gas meets specifications (moisture, cylinder pressure)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydrostatic test performed. (Table 12.1.2)
children.hint: Table 12.1.2 Hydrostatic test cylinders.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, external condition of pipes acceptable, without misalignment or trapped sections, fittings in proper location and in acceptable condition.  (11.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.2 System piping and fittings shall be inspected for the following: (1) Mechanical damage (e.g., broken piping or cracked fittings) (2) External conditions (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coatings, rust, and corrosion) (3) Misalignment or trapped sections  (3) Low-point drains (automatic or manual)  (5) Location and condition of rubber-gasketed fittings

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pipe hangers, supports & braces not missing, are securely attached, with acceptable external condition. (11.2.3)
children.hint: 11.2.3  Hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected for the following and repaired or replaced as necessary:  (1) Condition (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coating, rust, and corrosion)  (2) Secure attachment to structural supports and piping  (3) Damaged or missing hangers, braces, and supports

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam water discharge devices aimed properly, free from corrosion or external loading. (11.2.4.1)
children.hint: 11.2.4.1 Foam-water discharge devices shall be inspected visually and maintained to ensure that they are in place, continue to be aimed or pointed in the direction intended in the system design, and are free from external loading and corrosion.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Where caps/plugs are required, in place and free to operate as intended (11.2.4.2)
children.hint: 11.2.4.2 Where caps or plugs are required, the inspection shall confirm they are in place and free to operate as intended.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Discharge devices without unlisted combinations and foam concentrate unsubstituted.  (11.2.4.4)
children.hint: 11.2.4.4  Inspection shall verify that unlisted combinations of discharge devices and foam concentrate have not been substituted.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System auxiliary drains without leaks. (Table 11.5.1)
children.hint: Table 11.5.1 Auxiliary drains - Inspect for leaks at system working pressure.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Water supply inspected on regular schedule to ensure dependable operation and piping free of internal obstructions.  (11.2.5)
children.hint: 11.2.5.1 The dependability of the water supply shall be ensured by regular inspection and maintenance, whether furnished by a municipal source, on-site storage tanks, a fire pump, or private underground piping systems. 11.2.5.2 Water supply piping shall be maintained free of internal obstructions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Mainline and discharge device strainers without damage or corroded parts, and cleaned after each operation.  (11.2.6.1)
children.hint: 11.2.6.1 Mainline and individual discharge device strainers (basket or screen) shall be inspected every 5 years for damaged and corroded parts.   11.2.6.3 Discharge device strainers shall be removed, inspected, and cleaned during the flushing procedure for the mainline strainer.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam concentrate strainers inspected to ensure the blow-down valve is closed and plugged. (11.2.6.4)
children.hint: 11.2.6.4  Foam concentrate strainers shall be inspected visually to ensure the blow-down valve is closed and plugged.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Drainage facilities under and around system free of obstructions and unblocked, with dikes and retention embankments in good repair. (11.2.7)
children.hint: 11.2.7 Drainage. The area beneath and surrounding a foam water spray system shall be inspected to ensure that drainage facilities, such as trap sumps and drainage trenches, are not blocked, and retention embankments or dikes are in good repair.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valves in correct position (11.2.8.3)
children.hint: 11.2.8.3 The position (open or closed) of valves shall be verified in accordance with specified operating conditions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Quantity of foam concentrate in supply tank adequate (11.2.8.4)
children.hint: 11.2.8.4 Inspection of the concentrate tank shall include verification that the quantity of foam concentrate satisfies the requirements of the original design.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Strainer clear, pressure vacuum vent operating freely and power is available to pump. (11.2.8.5.3)
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.3 Line Proportioner. The inspection shall include the following: (1) Strainers  (2) Verification that pressure vacuum vent is operating freely  (3) An inspection for external corrosion on foam concentrate storage tanks

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Proportioning system operational test conducted manually and automatically to ensure proper responses. (11.3.2.1)
Take a picture of the issue
Record fire detection system response time for operation.  (11.3.2.5)
children.hint: 11.3.2.5 Response Time. Under test conditions, the automatic fire detection systems, when exposed to a test source, shall operate within the requirements of NFPA 72 for the type of detector provided, and the response time shall be recorded.

children.title: Record Time lapse from operation detection and water delivery to protected area.  (11.3.2.6)
children.hint: 11.3.2.6 Discharge Time. The time lapse between operation of detection systems and water delivery time to the protected area shall be recorded for open discharge devices.

children.title: Discharge patterns observed; discharge devices are not plugged or incorrectly positioned. (11.3.2.7)
children.hint: 11.3.2.7.1 The discharge patterns from all of the open spray devices shall be observed to ensure that patterns are not impeded by plugged discharge devices and to ensure that discharge devices are correctly positioned and that obstructions do not prevent discharge patterns from covering surfaces to be protected.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Record Pressure (psi) at highest, most remote discharge device.  (11.3.2.8.1)
children.hint: 11.3.2.8.1 Pressure readings shall be recorded at the highest, most remote discharge device.

children.title: Record Pressure (psi) at main control valve.  (11.3.2.8.2)
Samples of foam concentrate mixture taken during flow test and checked verifying concentration of solution within 10% of acceptance test results (11.3.5)
children.hint: 11.3.5.1 During the full flow foam test, a foam sample shall be taken.  11.3.5.2 Where approved by the authority having jurisdiction, simulated foam concentrates or alternative test systems shall be permitted to be substituted for actual foam concentrate, but system pressures and flows shall remain as described above and meet manufacturer’s system requirements and recommendations.  11.3.5.3 The foam sample shall be inspected by refractometric or other methods to verify concentration of the solution. 11.3.5.4 Concentration shall be within 10% of the acceptance test results but in no case more than 10% below minimum design standards

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam concentrate tank and pickup pipes inside tank inspected for corrosion, separation or plugging (11.4.5)
children.hint: 11.4.5.1 The foam concentrate tank shall be inspected for internal corrosion. 11.4.5.2 Pickup pipes inside the tank shall be inspected for corrosion, separation, or plugging.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam concentrate tank drained and flushed (11.4.5.3)
children.hint: 11.4.5.3 The foam concentrate tank shall be drained and flushed.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, external condition of pipes acceptable, without misalignment or trapped sections, fittings in proper location and in acceptable condition.  (11.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.2 System piping and fittings shall be inspected for the following: (1) Mechanical damage (e.g., broken piping or cracked fittings) (2) External conditions (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coatings, rust, and corrosion) (3) Misalignment or trapped sections  (3) Low-point drains (automatic or manual)  (5) Location and condition of rubber-gasketed fittings

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pipe hangers, supports & braces not missing, are securely attached, with acceptable external condition. (11.2.3)
children.hint: 11.2.3  Hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected for the following and repaired or replaced as necessary:  (1) Condition (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coating, rust, and corrosion)  (2) Secure attachment to structural supports and piping  (3) Damaged or missing hangers, braces, and supports

Foam water discharge devices aimed properly, free from corrosion or external loading. (11.2.4.1)
children.hint: 11.2.4.1 Foam-water discharge devices shall be inspected visually and maintained to ensure that they are in place, continue to be aimed or pointed in the direction intended in the system design, and are free from external loading and corrosion.

children.hint: 11.2.4.2 Where caps or plugs are required, the inspection shall confirm they are in place and free to operate as intended.

children.hint: 11.2.4.4  Inspection shall verify that unlisted combinations of discharge devices and foam concentrate have not been substituted.

System auxiliary drains without leaks. (Table 11.5.1)
children.hint: Table 11.5.1 Auxiliary drains - Inspect for leaks at system working pressure.

Foam concentrate strainers inspected to ensure the blow-down valve is closed and plugged. (11.2.6.4)
children.hint: 11.2.6.4  Foam concentrate strainers shall be inspected visually to ensure the blow-down valve is closed and plugged.

Valves in correct position (11.2.8.3)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Quantity of foam concentrate in supply tank adequate. (11.2.8.4)

Foam concentrate storage tank free of external corrosion, no foam in water around bladder. (11.2.8.5.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.2.2 The inspection shall include the following:   (2) An inspection for external corrosion on foam concentrate storage tanks  (3) An inspection for the presence of foam in the water surrounding the bladder (annual)

children.hint: 11.3.2.1 Operational tests shall be conducted to ensure that the foam-water system(s) responds as designed, both automatically and manually.

children.hint: 11.2.7 Drainage. The area beneath and surrounding a foam water spray system shall be inspected to ensure that drainage facilities, such as trap sumps and drainage trenches, are not blocked, and retention embankments or dikes are in good repair.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valves in correct position (11.2.8.3)
children.hint: 11.2.8.3 The position (open or closed) of valves shall be verified in accordance with specified operating conditions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Quantity of foam concentrate in supply tank adequate (11.2.8.4)
children.hint: 11.2.8.3 The position (open or closed) of valves shall be verified in accordance with specified operating conditions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Proportioning system operational test conducted manually and automatically to ensure proper responses. (11.3.2.1)
children.hint: 11.3.2.1 Operational tests shall be conducted to ensure that the foam-water system(s) responds as designed, both automatically and manually.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Record fire detection system response time for operation.  (11.3.2.5)
children.hint: 11.3.2.5 Response Time. Under test conditions, the automatic fire detection systems, when exposed to a test source, shall operate within the requirements of NFPA 72 for the type of detector provided, and the response time shall be recorded.

children.title: Record Time lapse from operation detection and water delivery to protected area.  (11.3.2.6)
children.hint: 11.3.2.6 Discharge Time. The time lapse between operation of detection systems and water delivery time to the protected area shall be recorded for open discharge devices.

children.title: Discharge patterns observed; discharge devices are not plugged or incorrectly positioned. (11.3.2.7)
children.hint: 11.3.2.7.1 The discharge patterns from all of the open spray devices shall be observed to ensure that patterns are not impeded by plugged discharge devices and to ensure that discharge devices are correctly positioned and that obstructions do not prevent discharge patterns from covering surfaces to be protected.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Record Pressure (psi) at highest, most remote discharge device.  (11.3.2.8.1)
children.hint: 11.3.2.8.1 Pressure readings shall be recorded at the highest, most remote discharge device.

children.title: Record Pressure (psi) at main control valve.  (11.3.2.8.2)
Samples of foam concentrate mixture taken during flow test and checked verifying concentration of solution within 10% of acceptance test results (11.3.5)
children.hint: 11.3.5.1 During the full flow foam test, a foam sample shall be taken.  11.3.5.2 Where approved by the authority having jurisdiction, simulated foam concentrates or alternative test systems shall be permitted to be substituted for actual foam concentrate, but system pressures and flows shall remain as described above and meet manufacturer’s system requirements and recommendations.  11.3.5.3 The foam sample shall be inspected by refractometric or other methods to verify concentration of the solution. 11.3.5.4 Concentration shall be within 10% of the acceptance test results but in no case more than 10% below minimum design standards

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Gauges in working order and sensing line valves and proportioner stations open. (11.2.8.5.5)
children.hint: 11.2.8.5.5 In-Line Balanced Pressure Proportioner. The inspection shall include the following: (3) Verification that gauges are in good working condition (4) Verification that sensing line valves at pump unit and individual proportioner stations are open

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam concentrate pump operated, foam concentrate circulated back to tank (11.4.6.1)
children.hint: 11.4.6.1 Pump Operation. 11.4.7.1.1 The foam concentrate pump shall be operated. 11.4.7.1.2 Foam concentrate shall be circulated back to the tank.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Diaphragm balancing valve flushed through diaphragm section with water or foam concentrate until fluid appears clear or new (11.4.7.3)
children.hint: 11.4.7.3 Flushing. The diaphragm balancing valve shall be flushed through the diaphragm section with water or foam concentrate until fluid appears clear or new.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam pump, drive train, and drivers serviced (11.4.7.2)
children.hint: 11.4.7.2 Servicing. Foam pumps, drive train, and drivers shall be serviced in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions and frequency but not at intervals of more than 5 years

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System piping free of mechanical damage, external condition of pipes acceptable, without misalignment or trapped sections, fittings in proper location and in acceptable condition.  (11.2.2)
children.hint: 11.2.2 System piping and fittings shall be inspected for the following: (1) Mechanical damage (e.g., broken piping or cracked fittings) (2) External conditions (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coatings, rust, and corrosion) (3) Misalignment or trapped sections  (3) Low-point drains (automatic or manual)  (5) Location and condition of rubber-gasketed fittings

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pipe hangers, supports & braces not missing, are securely attached, with acceptable external condition. (11.2.3)
children.hint: 11.2.3  Hangers, braces, and supports shall be inspected for the following and repaired or replaced as necessary:  (1) Condition (e.g., missing or damaged paint or coating, rust, and corrosion)  (2) Secure attachment to structural supports and piping  (3) Damaged or missing hangers, braces, and supports

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam water discharge devices aimed properly, free from corrosion or external loading. (11.2.4.1)
children.hint: 11.2.4.1 Foam-water discharge devices shall be inspected visually and maintained to ensure that they are in place, continue to be aimed or pointed in the direction intended in the system design, and are free from external loading and corrosion.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Where caps/plugs are required, in place and free to operate as intended (11.2.4.2)
children.hint: 11.2.4.2 Where caps or plugs are required, the inspection shall confirm they are in place and free to operate as intended.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Discharge devices without unlisted combinations and foam concentrate unsubstituted.  (11.2.4.4)
children.hint: 11.2.4.4  Inspection shall verify that unlisted combinations of discharge devices and foam concentrate have not been substituted.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System auxiliary drains without leaks. (Table 11.5.1)
children.hint: Table 11.5.1 Auxiliary drains - Inspect for leaks at system working pressure.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Water supply inspected on regular schedule to ensure dependable operation and piping free of internal obstructions.  (11.2.5)
children.hint: 11.2.5.1 The dependability of the water supply shall be ensured by regular inspection and maintenance, whether furnished by a municipal source, on-site storage tanks, a fire pump, or private underground piping systems. 11.2.5.2 Water supply piping shall be maintained free of internal obstructions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Mainline and discharge device strainers without damage or corroded parts, and cleaned after each operation.  (11.2.6.1)
children.hint: 11.2.6.1 Mainline and individual discharge device strainers (basket or screen) shall be inspected every 5 years for damaged and corroded parts.   11.2.6.3 Discharge device strainers shall be removed, inspected, and cleaned during the flushing procedure for the mainline strainer.

Foam concentrate strainers inspected to ensure the blow-down valve is closed and plugged. (11.2.6.4)
children.hint: 11.2.6.4  Foam concentrate strainers shall be inspected visually to ensure the blow-down valve is closed and plugged.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Ball drip valve free and open and foam concentrate tank without external corrosion. (11.2.8.5.1.2)
children.hint: 5 Yr Requirement - 11.2.8.5.1.1* The pressure shall be removed before the inspection to prevent injury.  11.2.8.5.1.2 The inspection shall verify the following:  (1) Ball drip valves (automatic drains) are free and opened.  (2) External corrosion on foam concentrate storage tanks is not present.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Foam liquid tank without corrosion & hydrostatically tested. (11.4.3.4)
children.hint: 11.4.3.4 The foam liquid tank shall be inspected for internal and external corrosion and hydrostatically tested to the specified working pressure.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Opening cleared of obstructions, vent body flushed and drained, valves cleaned, screen unclogged (11.4.8)
children.hint: 11.4.8.2 The vent shall be inspected to ensure that the opening is not blocked and that dirt or other foreign objects do not enter the tank. 11.4.8.5 The vent body shall be flushed internally, and the vacuum valve and the pressure valve shall be washed thoroughly. 11.4.8.6 The vent shall be inspected to ensure that the screen is not clogged, and the use of any hard, pointed objects to clear the screen shall be avoided. 11.4.8.7 If the liquid has become excessively gummy or solidified, the vent body and parts shall be soaked in hot soapy water.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Unit reassembled with appropriate lubrication, ensuring freedom of moveable parts (11.4.8)
children.hint: 11.4.8.10 Parts shall be sprayed with a light Teflon® coating, and the vent shall be reassembled. 11.4.8.12 The vent bonnet shall be replaced, and the vent shall be turned upside down slowly a few times to ensure proper freedom of the movable parts.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Detectors in place, securely fastened, & protected from mechanical damage & corrosion. (13.9.2)
children.hint: 13.9.2 Automatic detection equipment used to actuate waterbased fire protection systems that is not covered by NFPA 72 shall be inspected, tested, and maintained to ensure that the detectors are in place, securely fastened, and protected from corrosion, weather, and mechanical damage.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Communication wiring, control units, or tubing system is functional. (13.9.2)
children.hint: 13.9.2 Automatic detection equipment used to actuate waterbased fire protection systems that is not covered by NFPA 72 shall be inspected, tested, and maintained to ensure that the communication wiring, control panels, or pneumatic tubing system is functional.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Select equipment in the Fire Service Main
Hydrant accessible, without cracks in barrel or leaks in outlets or top of hydrant. (7.2.2.4)
children.hint: 7.2.2.4 Hydrants inspected for: (1) Inaccessibility, (4) Leaks in outlets or at top of hydrant

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Outlet caps tight, outlet threads and hydrant operating nut not worn and operating wrench available.  (7.2.2.4)
children.hint: 7.2.2.4 Hydrants inspected for: (6) Tightness of outlet caps (7) Worn outlet threads (8) Worn hydrant operating nut (9) Availability of operating wrench.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydrant opened fully and water flowed until all foreign material has cleared and proper drainage observed.  (7.3.2.1 & 7.3.2.3)
children.hint: 7.3.2.1 Each hydrant shall be opened fully and water flowed until all foreign material has cleared.  7.3.2.2 Flow shall be maintained for not less than 1 minute.   7.3.2.3 After operation, dry barrel and wall hydrants shall be observed for proper drainage from the barrel.  7.3.2.4 Full drainage shall take no longer than 60 minutes.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydrant parts lubricated.  (7.4.2.1)
children.hint: 7.4.2.1 Hydrants shall be lubricated annually to ensure that all stems, caps, plugs, and threads are in proper operating condition.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Type of hydrant outlet
children.hint: Select Outlet Type

children.title: Hydrant outlet size (flow hydrant)
children.hint: Indicate size of hydrant outlet or nozzle size of flowing hydrant.

children.title: Discharge coefficient (flow hydrant)
children.hint: Enter coefficient for the flow hydrant

children.title: Pitot pressure (flow hydrant)
children.hint: Enter pitot pressure for flow hydrant

children.title: Residual psi (residual hydrant)
children.hint: Enter residual psi for residual hydrant

children.title: Static psi  (residual hydrant)
children.hint: Enter static psi for residual hydrant

children.title: Flow test results show piping free of pipe degradation that would affect system performance. (7.3.1.1)
children.hint: 7.3.1  Underground and Exposed Piping Flow Tests. Underground and exposed piping serving hydrants shall be flow tested at minimum 5-year intervals.  7.3.1.1 Any flow test results that indicate deterioration of available waterflow and pressure shall be investigated to the complete satisfaction of the authority having jurisdiction to ensure that the required flow and pressure are available for fire protection.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Exposed piping free of leaks, physical damage, corrosion, hanging or restraint problems.  (7.2.2.1.2)
children.hint: 7.2.2.1.2  Piping shall be inspected, and the necessary corrective action shall be taken as specified in Table 7.2.2.1.2.   (1) Leaks (2) Physical damage (3) Corrosion (4) Restraint methods

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Strainers removed and inspected for plugging, fouling, damaged or corroded parts.  (7.2.2.3)
children.hint: 7.2.2.3.1 Mainline strainers shall be inspected and cleaned after each system flow exceeding that of a nominal 2 in. (50 mm) orifice.  7.2.2.3.2 Mainline strainers shall be removed and inspected annually for plugging, fouling, and damaged and corroded parts.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Monitor nozzle free of any leaking, corrosion or physical damage.  (7.2.2.6)
children.hint: 7.2.2.6 Monitor Nozzles. Monitor nozzles shall be inspected semiannually for the following conditions:  (1) Leakage  (2) Physical damage  (3) Corrosion

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Monitor nozzle oscillated & moved through full range & lubricated for proper operation. (7.3.3.2 & 7.4.3)
children.hint: 7.3.3.2 All monitor nozzles shall be oscillated and moved throughout their full range annually to ensure proper operability.  7.4.3 Monitor nozzles shall be lubricated annually to ensure proper operating condition.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydrant mounted monitor nozzle, tested for proper functioning.  (7.3.3.1)  Enter N/A if not applicable.
children.hint: 7.3.3.1 Monitor nozzles that are mounted on hydrants shall be tested as specified in 7.3.2.   7.3.2* Hydrants. Hydrants shall be tested annually to ensure proper functioning.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve Size
children.hint: Enter size of valve

children.title: Valve has proper signs, and is accessible.  (13.3.2.2)
children.hint: 13.3.2.2 The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (3) Accessible (6) Provided with applicable identification

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve is free of external leaks, and appropriate wrench available (13.3.2.2)
children.hint: 13.3.2.2 The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (4) Post indicator valves (PIVs) are provided with correct wrenches   (5) Free from external leaks

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve in normal open position and properly secured. (13.3.2.2)
children.hint: 13.3.2.2 The valve inspection shall verify that the valves are in the following condition: (1) In the normal open or closed position  (2) Sealed, locked, or supervised

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve exercised through full range to ensure proper operation.  (13.3.3.2)
children.hint: 13.3.3.2 Post indicator valves shall be opened until spring or torsion is felt in the rod, indicating that the rod has not become detached from the valve.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Valve Status Test - Valves open when returned to service.  (13.3.3.4)
children.hint: 13.3.3.4 A valve status test shall be conducted any time the control valve is closed and reopened at system riser.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Exterior of tank, supporting structure, vents, foundation and catwalks/ladders, where provided, free of obvious damage or weakening?  (9.2.4.1)
children.hint: 9.2.4.1 The exterior of the tank, supporting structure, vents, foundation, and catwalks or ladders, where provided, shall be inspected quarterly for signs of obvious damage or weakening.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Area around tank free of combustibles, corrosive materials or ice buildup, and embankment supporting tanks free of erosion.  (9.2.4.2)
children.hint: 9.2.4.2 The area surrounding the tank and supporting structure, where provided, shall be inspected quarterly to ensure that the following conditions are met: (1) The area is free of combustible storage, trash, debris, brush, or material that could present a fire exposure hazard. (2) The area is free of the accumulation of material on or near parts that could result in accelerated corrosion or rot. (3) The tank and support are free of ice buildup.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hoops and grillage free of damage.  (9.2.4.4)
children.hint: 9.2.4.4 The hoops and grillage of wooden tanks shall be inspected annually.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Exterior painted, coated or insulated surfaces and supporting structures, if provided, free of signs of degradation? (9.2.4.5)
children.hint: 9.2.4.5 Exterior painted, coated, or insulated surfaces of the tank and supporting structure, where provided, shall be inspected annually for signs of degradation.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Interior of tank free of damage, corrosion, deterioration, failure of interior coating or aquatic growth.  (9.2.5.3)
children.hint: 9.2.5.3 The tank interior shall be inspected for signs of pitting, corrosion, spalling, rot, other forms of deterioration, waste materials and debris, aquatic growth, and local or general failure of interior coating.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Silt drained from tank to avoid accumulation to the level of tank outlet.  (9.4.5)
children.hint: 9.4.5 Silt shall be removed during interior inspections or more frequently as needed to avoid accumulation to the level of the tank outlet

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Gauges on valve, when compared to calibrated gauge accurate within 3% of full scale or gauge has been recalibrated or replaced. (13.2.7.2 & 13.2.7.3)
children.hint: 13.2.7.2 Gauges shall be replaced every 5 years or tested every 5 years by comparison with a calibrated gauge. 13.2.7.3 Gauges not accurate to within 3 percent of the full scale shall be recalibrated or replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pressure (psi) shown on the pressure gauge on the tank. (Table 9.1.1.2)
children.hint: Table 9.1.1.2  The air pressure in pressure tanks that have their air pressure source supervised, shall be inspected quarterly.   Table  9.2.2.2 The air pressure in pressure tanks with a nonsupervised air pressure source shall be inspected monthly.

children.title: Level indicator operating accurately and has freedom of movement (9.3.1)

children.hint: 13.4.3.1.3 The preaction valve shall be externally inspected monthly to verify the following: (1) The valve is free from physical damage. (2) All trim valves are in the appropriate open or closed position. (3) The valve seat is not leaking. (4) Electrical components are in service.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue

children.hint: 9.5.3 Testing. All automatic tank fill valves shall be tested yearly in accordance with the following: (1) The valve shall be actuated automatically by lowering the water level in the tank. (2) The refill rate shall be measured and recorded.

children.hint: 13.2.5 Main Drain Test. A main drain test shall be conducted annually for each water supply lead-in to a building water based fire protection system to determine whether there has been a change in the condition of the water supply.

Liability Release Statement
children.calculate_expr: "The owner and/or designated representative acknowledges the responsibility of the operating condition of the component parts at the time of this inspection. It is agreed that the inspection service provided by the contractor as prescribed herein is limited to performing a visual inspection and/or routine testing, and any investigation or unscheduled testing, modification, maintenance, repair, etc., of the component parts is not included as part of the inspection work performed. It is further understood that all information contained herein is provided to the best of the knowledge of the party providing such information."
